title: 107_hr2313
content: The Act may be cited as the "Crane Tithe Tax Act of 2001" and repeals the taxation of corporations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals various tax provisions related to corporate income, alternative minimum tax for corporations, unrelated business income tax, accumulated earnings tax, personal holding company tax, alternative tax for certain mutual savings banks, and tax imposed on life insurance companies. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals various tax provisions for corporations, mutual savings banks, life insurance companies, mutual insurance companies, other insurance companies, regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, and income of foreign corporations connected with United States business. SEC. 3. 10 PERCENT INCOME TAX RATE FOR INDIVIDUALS. Section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to impose a 10 percent income tax rate for individuals. A 10 percent income tax is imposed on individuals based on the excess of earned income over the exemption amount, which is $10,000 adjusted for the cost of living. The exemption amount for individuals is $10,000 adjusted for the cost-of-living, calculated based on the CPI for October of the preceding calendar year compared to the CPI for October of 2000. The term 'CPI' refers to the Consumer Price Index for all-urban consumers published by the Department of Labor. Any increase not a multiple of $10 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. The term 'earned income' includes wages, salaries, net earnings from self-employment, and certain dividends from personal service corporations. The term 'earned income' includes wages, salaries, and certain dividends from personal service corporations, but excludes pensions, annuities, and tips at the discretion of the service-recipient. Fringe benefits are valued at employer cost. The cost to the employer of fringe benefits included as earned income shall be considered. Amnesty is granted for all prior tax liability before January 1, 2000, under the Internal Revenue Code. Exceptions include amounts paid before the enactment of the Act and taxes related to illegal activities. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to repeal specific exclusions, deductions, and credits for individuals. Additionally, estate, gift, and generation-skipping taxes are repealed. Effective dates are also specified. The amendments made by this Act apply to taxable years after enactment. The repeal of estate and gift taxes applies to estates of decedents dying after enactment. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit technical changes to the Committee on Ways and Means within 90 days of enactment. Within 90 days of enactment, the Secretary of the Treasury must submit technical changes to the Committee on Ways and Means regarding the Internal Revenue Code to reflect the changes made by this Act.
